column3: No time for Leg Day during #UFFinals?  We've got you. Come check out our test desk-ercisers and let us know what you think!
Always glad to host our beloved Beau!

Find your inner purr at a SPECIAL SESSION of guided meditation this Thursday, from 12-12:45pm, called "The Inner Smile".  Meet on the 2nd floor, in room C2-41C, to take some time and de-stress during finals.
Don't miss out!  We're hosting meditation this Wednesday at 12:15pm on our third floor, room C3-72.  Come and set your intention to succeed in your studies!
UF Health Science Center Libraries
Just a reminder!   Beau the Therapy Dog will be here THIS AFTERNOON!  From 1-2pm, on the first floor of the HSC Library.  #KeepCalmAndPetAPup #UFFinals #Breathe

24-hour access to our library is available for Health Science Center students. Ask for an application at the library's first floor Information Desk (allow 1-2 business days for processing).  

Find more information here: https://library.health.ufl.edu/about-us/library-user-policies/24hr-study-space/

Guess who's back...back again: our favorite therapy pup Beau!  He'll be helping cure a case of the Mondays and celebrating #WellnessWednesday on April 23rd & 25th, from 1-2pm on the library first floor!

#MeetTheLibraryMonday - Liaison Librarians

Our liaisons are librarians who specialize in a particular subject and who work with specific colleges, departments, centers or programs. Your liaison librarian is the first person you can call when you need help finding, selecting, or managing information.

Our liaisons are experts at searching databases of research data and literature, managing citations, creating data management plans, assisting with systematic reviews, and more! Your liaison can meet with you one-on-one, come guest lecture in your class, create tutorials that you can share online, or partner with your team on grants, publications, or research projects. #NationalLibraryWeek

Contact your Liaison Librarian today!
http://library.health.ufl.edu/services/library-liaisons/

Remember, our appreciation event and panel discussion about post-graduate careers in the libraries is tomorrow morning, 10:45 am!  Come enjoy some breakfast and learn about what life can look like on the other side of the degree.

Happy #ManateeAppreciationDay! Library staff member Bob shows his appreciation by printing this manatee skull using the HSC Library's 3D printers. Check out our other 3D printed models at the Information Desk, or submit a request of your own here: https://3dprint.uflib.ufl.edu/!

50 Million people have epilepsy world wide.

It is estimated that 1 in 100 people have epilepsy, and in 50% of cases the cause is unknown. Purple Day is an international grassroots effort dedicated to increasing awareness about epilepsy worldwide. On March 26th annually, people in countries around the world are invited to wear purple and host events in support of epilepsy awareness.

http://www.purpleday.org/
#purpleday2018 #purpleday #epilepsyawareness
Up and Running with Augmented Reality in Unity

It's officially the 1st day of Spring! Try a little mental spring cleaning by letting us help plan your assignments, using our handy Assignment Calculator at http://wap.uflib.ufl.edu/assigncalc/. Just enter when you want to start the assignment, and when it's due, and it will give you dates, steps and links for information related to planning, researching, and writing your assignment.

http://wap.uflib.ufl.edu/assigncalc/

In honor of National Poison Prevention Week, we're sharing this reminder that harmful substances don't always look like you think they would.  If you suspect that you or a loved one has ingested poison, call the National Poison Control hotline immediately: 1-800-222-1222.  If the person person collapses, has a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened you should call 911.

Upcoming event notice:  April 2 is World Autism Awareness Day.  On April 2nd, there will be a screening of the film "Deej"- a documentary about autism and inclusion.  The film will be screen at UF;s Reitz Union's Auditorium at 6PM- doors open at 5:15.

http://card.ufl.edu/2018/03/02/deej-movie-screening-and-discussion-4-2-18/

World Sleep Day brings awareness to the importance of sleep as crucial to good health. Poor sleep is linked to both physical and mental disorders, such as obesity, diabetes and depression.  College students are especially vulnerable to stressors that may interfere with sleep.  

For your health, get some sleep! 

#WorldSleepDay #NeedANap #NationalSleepAwarenessWeek
Happy 139th Birthday, Albert Einstein. Have some ?!

March 14 is National Write Down Your Story Day.  As the study of narrative in medicine shows, there is a value in telling one's story and increasingly more ways to narrate your own story and find those of others.  Check out Self Narrate in Gainesville- https://www.selfnarrate.com/ .  Or read oral histories from the Samuel Proctor Oral History Program- http://ufdc.ufl.edu/ohufhc and http://ufdc.ufl.edu/ohufcn

Happy National Sleep Awareness Week!  As you recover from Daylight Savings, check out this eBook, "The Science of Sleep", and learn more about the importance of good sleep hygiene.  http://uf.catalog.fcla.edu/permalink.jsp?20UFPDA002986972 #NeedANap
If you'd like to Create in Place on this, the end of Spring Break, we've got art supplies here at the library for you to use!  Come join us and #ExpressYourself.  #CreateInPlace #352Creates

We're so excited to send our librarians to the Medical Library Association's conference in Atlanta this May, and we hope that we'll see some of our friends from the Alachua County Library District and Jacksonville Public Library at the "Health Information for Public Librarians" symposium, which is FREE to U.S.-based public librarians with an interest in health information!
We're excited about the UF College of Dentistry's 4th Annual Super Sealant Saturday!  A chance for kids to get some free dental care, learn how to care for their teeth, and get a free toothbrush!
Making dolls for children- join us on the first Saturday of every month!  Our next doll making session will be April 7, 10:00 AM- 2:00 PM in the Health Science Center Library, Room C2-41A!

What better way to celebrate your triumphant return from Spring Break than by learning the latest tech tools that the library has to offer when it comes to finding, organizing, and presenting information?  

Also, free snacks and giveaways - who can say no to that?
Our favorite therapy dog Beau is being nominated for a national award!  Support our playful pupper pal by voting for him on the website linked below.

Here are the updated HSC Library hours for Spring Break:

Saturday, March 3rd - CLOSED
Sunday, March 4th - CLOSED
Monday, March 5th – Friday, March 9th - 7:30am-7pm
Saturday, March 10th - CLOSED
Sunday, March 11th - 1pm-11:30pm
Join us for the next Dollies without Borders doll making session on the Library second floor, room C2-41A, Saturday, March 3, 10am-2pm.  Help make dolls for children living in the developing world!

It's National Fairy Tale Day!  Take a break from studying and head to your local branch of the Alachua County Library District to find some books, or check out the fairy tales available online through George A. Smathers Libraries' Baldwin Library of Historical Children's Literature: http://ufdc.ufl.edu/UF00082991/00001/5.  #ReadAcrossAmerica

Student Government Elections are TODAY and TOMORROW, 2/20 & 2/21.  The Health Science Center polling location is actually here at the HSC Library, in room C2-41C.  Voting is open from 8:30am-8:30pm both days.

On Presidents' Day, we remember when the National Institutes of Health (NIH) were first founded, and the timeless words spoken by President Roosevelt at the dedication: "Today the need for the conservation of health and physical fitness is greater than at any time in the nation’s history. In dedicating this Institute, I dedicate it to the underlying philosophy of public health, to the conservation of life, to the wise use of the vital resources of our nation. I voice for America, and for the stricken world, our hopes, our prayers, our faith, in the power of man’s humanity to man.”

Watch the full dedication here, through the National Library of Medicine (NLM)'s Digital Collections archive (full record available here: http://resource.nlm.nih.gov/101205101). #PresidentsDay

On Abraham Lincoln's birthday, we at the HSC Library remember the efforts of those who were with President Lincoln in his final hours; in particular, Dr. Anderson Abbott, a prominent black physician who worked as a civilian surgeon in the Union army.  In recognition for his service, First Lady Mary Todd Lincoln gifted him with a shawl the President had worn at his first inauguration.  

Read some of Dr. Abbott's reflections on his involvement in such an historic event here: https://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433081752911?urlappend=%3Bseq=399.  #BlackHistoryMonth

Image Credit: Toronto Public Library

Tomorrow is the beginning of the 5th annual I Love Local Food Week 2018, hosted by Working Food, a local non-profit organization that supports the North Central Florida food community!  They'll be hosting a variety of events throughout the week to educate and raise awareness about farms and food from our region.  

Here at the HSC library, we're particularly excited about their new book club, featuring the book "Blood Sugar: Racial Pharmacology and Food Justice", which meets for the first time on Monday, February 12th, at 12pm.  

Learn more about the event and its sponsor here: https://workingfood.org/working-food-events/book-club-blood-sugar-racial-pharmacology-and-food-justice/. #FriYAY
We're so excited to have Ariel Pomputius and Maggie Ansell represent the George A. Smathers Libraries at ALA Midwinter with their innovative Wellness Programming proposal!

Tomorrow is National Black AIDS Day, and in observance of this day, the Office of Minority Health - U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Resource Center is hosting a webinar TODAY, at 12:30pm: Fact or Fiction: Debunking HIV Myths in the Black Community.  Register for the webinar here: https://register.gotowebinar.com/register/224892297143665153 

If you can't make it to the webinar, check out the HSC Library's video about HIV myths, made in partnership with the UF Center for Arts in Medicine.https://youtu.be/fHlTVBETcC4 #NBHAAD

The first week of February is African Heritage and Health Week!  To learn more about how African culinary traditions can improve heart health and more, check out these resources from Oldways, an organization that hosts classes on different culinary traditions: https://oldwayspt.org/programs/african-heritage-health/african-heritage-health-resources

There is also much we can learn about health from traditional African medicine.  One great source of information is AJTCAM: the African Journal of Traditional Complementary and Alternative Medicines.  Check out the latest issue here: http://journals.sfu.ca/africanem/index.php/ajtcam/index.  

#HeartMonth #BlackHistoryMonth

Today we #WearRed in order to raise awareness of heart health for women, as part of the HSC Library's celebration of #HeartMonth.  Heart disease is the leading cause of death for women, but there are many ways to reduce your risk!  Check out these information resources on women's heart health:

Heart Health for Women (FDA): https://permanent.access.gpo.gov/gpo63354/UCM444196.pdf
 
Heart Disease in Women (NLM): https://medlineplus.gov/heartdiseaseinwomen.html 

Image Caption: Gator Marching Band members form a heart shape. (UF Digital Collections: UF00031569)

Dr. Miriam Harris, author of Hidden Human Computers, will be visiting the George A. Smathers Libraries to present her work as part of the African American Studies Program’s Ronald Foreman Lecture Series. 

Thursday, February 8th
6pm
Smathers 100

January 28th is data privacy day.  In an era where maintaining health records electronically is becoming the norm and researchers are conducting more clinical studies, the ability to keep data private becomes critical.  At UF, ResearchVault (https://www.rc.ufl.edu/services/restricted-data/researchvault/)  is a great resource for data storage and it meets several criteria for data privacy including HIPAA for health data.  Also, check out the HIPAA Summit that is taking place from March 27th – 29th (https://hipaasummit.com/).
In light of this year's aggressive flu season, UF Health is temporarily changing policies related to visitation and infection control:

Conversations with our patients about their health can be emotional and sometimes contentious.  Join us at Alachua County Library District to discuss how to have meaningful dialogue on difficult topics.

In week 3 of our #MeetTheLibraryMonday posts, meet a familiar face to our night owl library patrons - Victoria!  

What's your favorite thing about the library?
My favorite resource is 3D printing since they are fun to do. 

What do you do when you're not working?
My hobbies: singing, reading, makeup, and gaming.

What are you currently reading?
“My First Five Husbands… and the Ones Who Got Away” by Rue McClanahan

Spend Summer B in Madagascar! This experiential course concentrates on biodiversity, conservation, sustainability, and culture, and how these factors interact in a developing country. Madagascar is a unique and amazing place, with incredible biodiversity and fascinating culture. Over 80% of the organisms living there are endemic, and this is the only place where you will see lemurs in the wild. Come to Madagascar and learn from local experts, experience the culture, and explore the natural world of the Eighth Continent.

For more information, contact Dr. Michele Tennant (tennantm@ufl.edu) or visit us at the Spring Study Abroad Fair, Wednesday, January 24, 10:00-3:00, north lawn of Reitz Union.

Did you know that the HSC Library offers free workshops on a variety of topics, including managing your citations with EndNote or Mendeley, searching for literature in PubMed, CINAHL, or Web of Science, and using bioinformatics tools like UGENE, EBI, or BLAST?  We have over 30 workshops scheduled this semester, all designed to help students, instructors, and researchers improve how they study, teach, and investigate.

Check out our schedule of workshops for the spring semester here: http://library.health.ufl.edu/2018/01/16/library-classes/.  

All workshops are free and open to the public.
Study Abroad Fair

Our next guest on #MeetTheLibraryMonday is familiar to most of our patrons: Bob!  Let's learn more about one of the HSC Library's friendliest faces:

What's your favorite thing about the library?
All the new WELLNESS activities!

What do you do when you're not working?
Read, hike & bike the trails, go to the beaches (on both coasts!), play my bass guitar. 

What are you currently reading/watching?
Medicine and Compassion by C. Rinpoche, Gentlemen of the Road by Michael Chabon, Jamaica by Ian Fleming, and I only watch PBS.

January 12th is National Pharmacist day.  Take the time to appreciate your pharmacist for all that he or she does.  Pharmacists aren’t limited to working behind the counter and filling prescriptions.  When emergency occurs pharmacists can also respond and save lives.  For instance, the quick thinking and action of pharmacists Bhavini Patel and Ritesh Shah helped save lives.  Click on the links below to read the stories.
 
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/cvs-pharmacist-saves-man-having-food-allergy-epipen/ 
 
https://patch.com/new-jersey/middletown-nj/keansburg-pharmacist-saves-womans-life

The HSC Library has an amazing group of Access Services staff that keep us in business, from managing our study rooms to helping our users find full text!  Over the next month or so, the library will be introducing different staff members, their roles, and what they like to do when they're not behind our Information Desk!  #MeetTheLibraryMonday
